Hey, this is the design head from Team 701 The Robovikes and I’d like feedback from other designers and mechanical committee members on how I should move forward with this pivoting chute concept. It’s designed with the intention to move out of the way during endgame for deep cage climb via the Penn State climbing mechanism you can see on the bottom with the polycarb. I haven’t designed them yet, but I plan on adding hard stops for both the top and bottom so it can position with as close to 100% consistency as possible. I also don’t know how wiring this would look like so it would be nice if anyone in electrical could point some things out too. I also ensured that the tubing wouldn’t get in the way of the coral so the chute is pretty wide and intaking shouldn’t be an issue. Also, I don’t know if the fixed arm can be designed with a chute and still be fixed, but that idea has been recommended to me as well to remove the chute completely.

If you are doing this in order to make room for a deep climb, keep in mind you cannot be in contact with the chain of cage for more than a momentary amount of time.

This does a good job of clearing space for a climber.

Watch out for top heaviness.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-01-19T20:38:44.798Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":162,"readers_count":161,"score":57.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":482679,"topic_slug":"pivoting-chute-reefscape-prototype-idea","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66015,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Design Head"},"post_url":"/t/pivoting-chute-reefscape-prototype-idea/482679/3","custom_user_title":"Design Head","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3487652,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-19T20:43:02.412Z","cooked":"

Ensure the mechanisms backdrives when hit. Your driver will slam it into a wall, and allowing the mechanism to backdrive when hit will just move the mechanisms instead of stressing the components.

Additionally, pocketing boxtube significantly weakens it due to introducing stress risers and splitting the beam into multiple weak beams. If you need lighter weight, using large holes on the top and bottom will lighten the tube without splitting the beam in the primary bending axis, which will improve strength.

You’re going to want to move the cage as far into the center of the robot to avoid tipping and touching the carpet.

Right now with where the cage sits in your robot, I will venture to guess the front end will tip forward and touch the carpet.

IIRC Penn state added quite a lot of counter balance to their robot to offset the non-centered climb.

Do you suppose a steel bellypan and added superstructure with battery on the cage side would counterbalance the other side? Currently the robot’s CG is in the middle of the carriage when the elevator is retracted. There’s also holes in the 2x1 tubing in the middle to allow wiring to both sides of the chassis.

Wiring doesn’t look like it would be too much of an issue with this design. It may just be slightly annoying to feed all the wire up the tubing.
Do you have to move the funnel out of the way when you extend the elevator? It looks like it is in the elevator’s clearance zone in a few photos, so you may want to look into a way you can design this where you don’t have to move it every time you extend the end effector

Well the original plan was to have its starting configuration down, and stay down until endgame. And also yes, it will get in the way of the elevator once its up and extended which is why I need to design hard stops for it as well.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-01-19T20:59:41.219Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":98,"readers_count":97,"score":19.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":482679,"topic_slug":"pivoting-chute-reefscape-prototype-idea","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":52449,"username":"BradenLynn3937","name":"Braden Lynn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bradenlynn3937/{size}/192207_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66015,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Design Head"},"post_url":"/t/pivoting-chute-reefscape-prototype-idea/482679/9","custom_user_title":"Design Head","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3487676,"name":"","username":"Banji","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/banji/{size}/224441_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-19T21:01:49.759Z","cooked":"

originally we were opting for a drawbridge design, with the spool being on the other end of the elevator superstructure and it would essentially just be a winch. While designing it though, I ran into an issue of how I was going to connect it. Nevertheless, I came up with pivoting chute as we know it right now as a backup, but I might switch to the drawbridge if it’s more practical and less complex than pivot.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-01-19T21:01:49.759Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":93,"readers_count":92,"score":33.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":482679,"topic_slug":"pivoting-chute-reefscape-prototype-idea","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":52449,"username":"BradenLynn3937","name":"Braden Lynn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bradenlynn3937/{size}/192207_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66015,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Design Head"},"post_url":"/t/pivoting-chute-reefscape-prototype-idea/482679/10","custom_user_title":"Design Head","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3487681,"name":"Braden Lynn","username":"BradenLynn3937","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bradenlynn3937/{size}/192207_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-19T21:13:27.319Z","cooked":"

Have you looked at dropping the funnel down instead. You could use the drawbridge design with the spool on the opposite side of the robot in the chassis to lower your CoG. It involves some pulleys, but it makes wiring and maintenance of the structure a bit easier if its in the robot base. When you extend the spool, the funnel would drop and give you the vertical space you need for Deep Cage

Screenshot 2025-01-19 150922456×550 29.8 KB

Screenshot 2025-01-19 150935537×546 27.4 KB

No I haven’t, that may actually be a really good idea. I actually have a meeting with our team in 40 minutes to discuss the design of our robot and I believe this would function only if the chute was very slim, some factors to consider would of course be the wall height as to not allow coral to slip out but it could just funnel in as long as its long enough and can become compact enough to allow for deep cage climb. However our elevator was designed with the intention of being in the middle to keep the CG low and towards the middle. I’d have to look into it, but thank you so much for this idea!
